title: Sighing
intro: In this programme, Dan and Catherine discuss sighing, and learn how it is in fact a vital human activity that keeps us healthy - and teach you six items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: How many times do mice sigh in an hour, on average?
a) Twice b) 10 times c) 40 times
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: something that your body does without thinking to keep you alive
to make something work again by going back to original settings
a physical action you can’t control

vocab.text: to breathe a sigh of relief
vocab.desc: to feel better after worrying about something
the feeling of being annoyed because you can’t do something
the feeling of accepting something bad that you cannot change

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English – the programme where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary. I’m Dan. And today we’re talking about...

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Sighing. I’m Catherine.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Now – was that a real sigh – or just one to demonstrate the meaning?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: That one was just for educational purposes, of course, Dan.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We’ll be looking at why we sigh, and learn how sighing keeps us alive!

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, very interesting. And it’s not just humans that sigh, is it, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Indeed, most mammals sigh. And that brings me to today’s question. How many times does a mouse sigh in an hour, on average? Is it?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: I’m going to say the poor little thing will sigh about 40 times an hour

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: OK. Let’s find out if you’re right later on in the programme. Now, what is a sigh, exactly?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Let’s hear from Dr Lynne Barker, a cognitive neuroscientist from Sheffield Hallam University in the UK.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: INSERT Dr Lynne Barker, Cognitive Neuroscientist, Sheffield Hallam University It’s a typically cardio-respiratory kind of resetting mechanism, and most mammals will engage in sighing of some kind. Because people who don’t sigh would eventually die. It is a survival mechanism .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: So sighing keeps us alive.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Dr Barker called it a survival mechanism . To survive means to continue living, especially in difficult circumstances. A mechanism , here, means a system of behaviour.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: So, a survival mechanism is something the body does automatically in order to survive. But, Dan, why is sighing a survival mechanism ?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: It’s because sighing can reset the lungs. To reset is to return something to its original settings. We often use this verb when talking about technology. You can reset a computer or a phone.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: OK, that’s fine. But how does a sigh reset the lungs?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, scientists from UCLA, that’s the University of California, Los Angeles, found that a sigh is a special kind of very deep breath that keeps the tiny sacs of air in our lungs, called alveoli, working properly.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And without sighing, these alveoli would collapse and we would die. We need the alveoli to transfer oxygen from our lungs to our blood.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Thankfully, we don’t have to think about this need to reset our lungs. Sighing is in fact a reflex .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Boo!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Argh!

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: There – you jumped! And that was a fabulous reflex , Dan! It’s something our bodies do without thinking, something you do unconsciously or automatically.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I meant… argh… like a man. Thank you for that, Catherine.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: You’re welcome. Dan Do you sigh a lot?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, I sigh when I’m tired, and I sigh when I’m relieved. I breathe a sigh of relief .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: To breathe a sigh of relief – that’s a great expression. It means what you think it means – to sigh when you feel good that something bad has not happened – but it’s often used metaphorically. It relates more to the feeling of relief than the act of sighing.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: That’s right. Now, I breathed a sigh of relief when I found my mobile phone the other day. I thought I’d lost it. It was new. I was so pleased when I found it! What about you, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I tend to sigh to show frustration . And sometimes resignation .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Now, frustration is what we feel when things aren’t going well, when things are annoying us and they don’t work. When things are frustrating .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And resignation is what we feel when we finally accept that something bad has happened, that we can’t change. We feel resigned to something.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: So, relief, resignation, frustration, resetting our lungs. It sounds like we humans never stop sighing!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, actually, we humans sigh on average 12 times an hour. But what about… mice?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, I said, I reckon they sigh about 40 times an hour.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, in fact, it is 40 times an hour. The hearts of mice beat faster – so they need to regulate their lungs more than humans.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Let’s review today’s vocabulary.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We had the phrase survival mechanism . Something we do without thinking that keeps us alive.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: We often use this phrase, and the related phrase defence mechanism, when talking about what people do to cope with difficulties in life.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Next, we had reset . You can reset a computer, or a machine – to make it work again. This usually means switching it off and on again.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And you can reset a password – this is a little bit different. It means to set – or choose - a new password.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We also had the word reflex . This is a physical action or reaction that you can’t control. For example… Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: There, you closed your eyes. Another reflex .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And we had to breathe a sigh to relief . Which means to feel better after something bad doesn’t happen. I breathed a sigh of relief when my friend recovered from her illness.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: But we sigh for other reasons too. Two useful sighing words were: frustration and resignation .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Frustration is the state of being frustrated . We can say something is frustrating . It’s frustrating when the boss doesn’t listen to me.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: But let’s say you move beyond feeling frustrated and start feeling resigned .

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yeah, and that would be when I finally accept the boss will never listen to me. And that’s when I’ll resign !

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: To resign also means to voluntarily leave a job! Please, Catherine, tell me that’s just another vocabulary example?!

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Of course it is, Dan. I love my job! I only ever sigh, what, 12 times an hour?!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Which is perfectly average. And that's it for today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And we are on social media too. Make sure to find us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
